title: 112_hr2809
content: The Act titled "Microenterprise and Youth Entrepreneurship Development Act of 2011" includes a program for microenterprise technical assistance and capacity building. The Riegle Community Development and Regulatory Improvement Act of 1994 is amended to include definitions for entrepreneurs operating in investment areas. Additionally, the permitted uses of assistance under the Act are expanded to support these entrepreneurs. The Riegle Community Development and Regulatory Improvement Act of 1994 is amended to include provisions for advertising training and technical assistance. Targeted assistance is increased to 60 percent, and matching requirements are adjusted to consider the impact of the 2007-2009 economic crisis on applicants' geographic areas. The Administrator of the Small Business Administration will submit a report with recommendations for improving the microenterprise technical assistance grant program within 180 days of the Act's enactment. Additionally, a Microenterprise Coordinator must be established within one year. The Administrator of the Small Business Administration will establish the position of Microenterprise Coordinator within one year of the Act's enactment. The Coordinator's duties include maximizing microenterprises' contributions to the economy, coordinating federal assistance programs, and ensuring underserved entrepreneurs are included in these programs. The Small Business Administration will establish a Microenterprise Coordinator position to oversee federal programs supporting microenterprises. The Coordinator will compile and publish an annual list of these programs and promote public-private partnerships for entrepreneurship. Microenterprise is defined as per the Riegle Community Development and Regulatory Improvement Act of 1994. The Small Business Administration will establish a Microenterprise Coordinator position to oversee federal programs supporting microenterprises, defined as per the Riegle Community Development and Regulatory Improvement Act of 1994. Additionally, there will be an Office of Youth Entrepreneurship established. The Small Business Administration will establish an Office of Youth Entrepreneurship, with a Director appointed to oversee programs promoting youth entrepreneurship through grants, partnerships, and advertising campaigns. The Small Business Administration will establish an Office of Youth Entrepreneurship to promote youth entrepreneurship through grants, partnerships, and advertising campaigns. The Director will also establish grant programs for technical assistance and curriculum development for individuals under 25 years of age. The Director may provide grants to covered entities for youth entrepreneurship curriculum development, including topics like securing capital, business planning, accounting, management, and marketing. Covered entities must submit an application detailing the curriculum and grant fund usage. The Director provides grants to covered entities for youth entrepreneurship curriculum development, focusing on topics like securing capital, business planning, accounting, management, and marketing. Covered entities must submit an application detailing the use of grant funds, goals related to the curriculum, and how progress will be measured. Additionally, at least 25% of the funds each year are allocated to assist youth in investment areas. The Director provides grants to covered entities for youth entrepreneurship curriculum development, focusing on topics like securing capital, business planning, accounting, management, and marketing. At least 25% of the funds each year are used to assist youth in investment areas. The Director, in consultation with the Secretary of Education, will submit a report to Congress with recommendations for legislation on forgiving and deferring student loans to support youth entrepreneurship and business formation. The GAO will conduct a study and submit a report. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on the economic impact of youth entrepreneurs deferring student loan repayments, increasing participation of individuals under 25 in the microloan program, alternative creditworthiness measures for youth entrepreneurship, and actions Congress should take to promote youth entrepreneurship. A report must be submitted within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Comptroller General will submit a report to the House and Senate Small Business Committees on the results of the study conducted under this Act.
